content:
I've just fixed the typo mentioned in Regulus136's comment below.

I've also moved the constraint ("answer and attempt always have a length of 5 letters") from Output section to Constraints section.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one, the special case of the repeated letters offer some interesting complexity

Just a typo:
- R is not answer
=>
- R is not in answer

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea and clear description! I prefer it as an easy puzzle, 15 minutes might not be enough to solve in a Clash for most players, but definitely has potential there as well!
It's a nice twist to a classic game. I think it's a good clash because the rules are easy to understand and it speaks common game language that most people will understand right away.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle.

Goal section
* Please change "not in the word" to "not in [[answer]]" because "word" is not well-defined (though understood).

* Suggest to change "result should indicate if the letter is also repeated in answer" to:
the result should be based on the following priority:
1. <<#>> for the letter appearing at the right place
2. <<O>> for the letter's earlier occurrences in [[attempt]]
3. <<X>> for the letter's remaining occurrences

Constraints section
* Please mention that [[answer]] and [[attempt]] always consist of 5 letters.

(Just curious, why are the cases restricted to 5-letter words?)

Thanks.

I just tried to do this as fast as I could. I think it might work as a Clash of Code. Plenty of people might not finish it within the clash time limit, but that happens on some clashes. Let's see what other reviewers have to say.

Hi Timinator,
I wasn't sure when I started writing it, however after Writing the solution I think you're right.

Hey 5DN1L,
Tnkas for your comment.
I've applied your suggestions.
The restriction to 5 letters comes from the Wordle game of NY times which is always 5 letters long : https://www.nytimes.com/games/wordle/index.html
As an approver, would you mind commenting on the difficulty level. Is it appropriate as an easy puzzle or should it be a class?
I also liked the test cases!

I mean there is not much to say about the difficulty, you just need to code what the problem asks you for, so it is easy. However I like the fact that this is inspired from a real game and maybe it will encourage beginners into programming. I like this as a puzzle not really a clash.

Ah, of course :) I confused myself with the CodinGame version of Wordle, which allows longer words :P
https://www.codingame.com/multiplayer/optimization/wordle

Hey there nicof6786 and 5DN1L -- how's it going? 

After this change, unfortunately, I am still a bit confused by the directions governing the case where there are more unmatched letters in attempt than answer.  I humbly propose consolidating paragraphs 1 and 3 of the directions as follows:

You are given the [[answer]] to today's <<Wordle>> and a list of [[N]] [[attempt]]s to solve it.
For each [[attempt]], you must print 5 characters corresponding to the 5 letters of [[attempt]] consisting of:
- the character <<#>> if the letter is at the right place
- the character <<O>> if the letter is in [[answer]] but at another place (additionally: if there are <<a>> occurrences of the letter in incorrect places in [[attempt]] and <<b>> occurrences of the letter in incorrect places in [[answer]], only the first <<min(a,b)>> occurrences of the letter going from left to right that are in incorrect places in [[attempt]] should be assigned the character <<O>>)    
- the character <<X>> for all other cases

Thanks!

Hi blast_beat, thank you for your suggestion. How about this instead?

You are given the [[answer]] to today's <<Wordle>> and a list of [[N]] [[attempt]]s to solve it.

For each [[attempt]], you must print 5 characters corresponding to the 5 letters of [[attempt]] consisting of:
- {{#}} if the letter is at the right place
- {{O}} if the letter is in [[answer]] but at another place
- {{X}} for all other cases

Additionally, if a particular letter appears in [[attempt]] and in [[answer]] a different number of times, the result should be based on the following priority:
1. {{#}} for correctly placed letters,
2. {{O}} for misplaced letters which appear earlier in [[attempt]],
3. {{X}} for any excess appearances.
I think that is a definite improvement, thanks!  There is still a tiny bit of ambiguity around what is meant by "earlier" and "excess", but it is probably obvious enough to people.

Thanks! I've updated the description accordingly. After a fresh look at the original statement I find that there are references to the word "result" in other parts. So, I've added back the word in the updated description for consistency.

Let's wait and see whether nicof6786 and others have any comments on the new wording or suggesting any further changes.
